headline: Traditional Filipino Lumpia
description: Filipino lumpia are fried spring rolls filled with a savory mixture of pork, cabbage, and other veggies usually served as a side dish or appetizer.

video.description: The Filipino version of egg rolls stuffed with pork and cabbage.
video.name: Filipino Lumpia

name: Traditional Filipino Lumpia
recipeIngredient: 2 cups vegetable oil for frying, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 1 tablespoon vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add pork; cook and stir until crumbly and no pink is showing, 5 to 7 minutes. Remove pork from the pan and set aside. Drain grease from the pan, leaving just a thin coating.

Add onion and garlic to the pan; cook and stir until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Stir in the cooked pork, carrots, green onions, cabbage, and cilantro. Season with pepper, salt, garlic powder, and soy sauce. Remove from the heat, and set aside until cool enough to handle, about 5 minutes.

Assemble lumpia: Place 3 heaping tablespoons of filling diagonally near one corner of a lumpia wrapper, leaving a 1 1/2 inch space at both ends. Fold the side along the length of the filling over the filling, tuck in both ends, and roll neatly and tightly to close. Moisten the other side of the wrapper with water to seal the edge. Transfer to a plate and cover with plastic wrap to retain moisture. Repeat to assemble remaining lumpia.
Heat 1/2 inch vegetable oil in a heavy skillet over medium heat for 5 minutes.

Slide 3 to 4 lumpia into the hot oil, making sure the seams are facing down. Fry, turning occasionally, until all sides are golden brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate to drain. Repeat to fry remaining lumpia. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: I loved the recipe! BTW I veganized it with vegan pork crumbles. It came out so well that my friends from the Philippines couldn't tell the difference! They even said it tasted better than the meat one. Just a tip, better tasting food is always vegan. Impossible Foods has a vegan beef and a vegan pork crumble and so does Beyond Foods. I personally like Impossible better, but Beyond is just as good. You can find these in any supermarket, like Shoprite and Stop and Shop. These came out so well so i recommend that you try it veganized (it is better for yourself and it frankly just tastes better that meat!).

My office mates love it. Even though I'm Filipino I never bothered making it from scratch, because I don't usually cook. I made it for my office potluck contribution here in the US. I usually buy them already prepared and Frozen. But Sorry I need to correct that this is not "Traditional" because in the Philippines you cannot easily buy Cilantro in many Public market where many regular Filipino folks buy. And sometimes limited if available. And many Filipino dish does not use Cilantro. And Cilantro can really alter the flavor / smell of any dish.
These things are the greatest! Follow the recipe explicitly. They are a crowd favorite!
I made it just as the recipe said and it turned out delicious.
My kids loved it and that's good enough for me. Thank you for sharing the recipe.
I like it. Very good.

I have tried lumpias, but all have had green beans. Will have to give this one a try.
I would like to suggest , to show us how to make the wrappers, please.
Great recipe I went with 1.5 lbs of pork. Everything else followed to the letter. Only suggestion is to go easy on the salt because pork is already salty. Other than tha, this was easy and tasty.
Delicious
easy breezy.... delicious. definitely took me back to my navy stint in the Phillipines

Loved the recipe! My only problem is that you cannot find lumpia wrappers ANYWHERE!!! I had to use spring roll wrappers and by far it wasn’t the same. I used to make lumpia religiously but since moving to NC I pretty much gave up.

Absolutely delicious!! My aunt is Filipino and we all anxiously wait for the holiday to indulge in them. Hers are authentic and impossible to stop eating. I took the recommendations from other reviews... doubled the cabbage, added box choy, oyster sauce, garlic powder, and ginger. They turned out NEARLY as good as hers!!

These were good, but extremely salty. I would omit the salt next time. They were also meat-heavy, I would probably double all the vegetables. I got 20 lumpia instead of 30, maybe doubling the vegetables would allow you to reach 30 lumpia, as well as improving the texture and flavor. There’s also an error in the directions: there is no way to get 30 lumpia if you use three heaping tablespoons of filling in each, lol. I used one heaping tablespoon each and got 20 lumpia. My family loved them though!
I couldn’t get the rice paper to fold properly without being wetted. And then I wetted it so then it couldn’t be fried. Need better instructions.

AMAZING. I made sweet chili sauce to go with it and they were absolutely delicious. 

45 minutes for prep though...you must do this everyday! The whole thing start to finish took me several hours, and the wrapping takes a bit of practice. Totally worth the finished product though!
Great recipe! Instead of deep frying, we brush (or spray) them with oil and air fry at 400 for 13 min (flip halfway through). These pair well with gochujang or duck sauce as a dipping sauce!
Most excellent
First, time ever making this. It was easy, fun and taste. The whole family enjoyed these. Will definitely make again.

Finding lumpia wrappers was the hardest part of this recipe. I followed all the measurements as instructed. Only difference was that I used the food processor to chop all the vegetables so they’d be the same consistency. Except the garlic for which I used pre-minced out of a jar - 2 tsps. This is super easy and tasty!! My husband and son said now we have no reason to go out to eat. I think I might have inadvertently caused myself to have to cook more.
Added more cabbage, but other than that I stuck to the recipe. Made half with no meat for the vegetarian in the house. Even had three different sauces with it. Great recipe. THANKS

Very good! Similar to how my Filipino BIL makes them. Out of habit, I seasoned the meat a little and next time I would omit the salt and use a little adobo seasoning for a tad bit more flavor as Emessina did. Thanks for the recipe!
I have not made it yet, but will. However, I will use beef or chicken, because I do not ever eat pork.
It was great. I used some leftover smoked pork I had onhand finely diced. Mighty tasty!

I made it exactly the recipe says except had to use shallots in place of green onions as I didn’t have any. But it tasted really good, and thought the amount of salt, black pepper, garlic powder and soy sauce was just right( amongs everything else). My family loved it, and said it’s better than any other lumpish that they had tasted before. I don’t have any experience cooking Filipino food but it’s easy enough for a beginner to cook. Using food processor to mince everything really helps since it’s a labor intensive dish:)

Replaced:
Pork with ground beef

It was a good base recipe! I had been taught and Americanized version but I liked this one much better! 

I added fresh cilantro and ginger since I needed to use them anyway. It added a bit more flavor but I'm very happy with the result!

Used a half green cabbage, doubled the onion, doubled most spices, add ginger!!!!, and added 3/4 lbs ground beef and a bit of celery and some arugula I had in the fridge. Still had 4 egg roll wrappers left over out of a pack of 25. Oh, and I used spring roll wrappers, which are thinner and give a great crispness. My parents lived on Guam for a few years and this is super close to what they make. Could probably use more carrot.

Hit with the family. Even made our own wrappers and they turned out decent. All 5 kids loved it and asked for seconds. That never happens with picky eaters. Definitely will be making again. Plus extras to freeze for a quick dinner as others suggested. It made 18 rolls
Very delicious and yummy, But I need to add the Onion on the dish, and I think it looks okay, but not too burnt.
These lumpias are scrumptious
Turned out great! Not too sweet and just moist enough. It's more of a bread than a cake. Not as moist as traditional carrot cake.
I made this recipe exactly as written under the supervision of a filipino friend and it the end result was approved!
It was great!!
Really yummy. Just added more carrots

My first time making lumpia. I did 1-1/2 times the recipe (1.5 lbs of ground pork) and followed the recipe exactly, and they turned out delicious! It takes a bit to get the rolling down, but after the first couple, it was easy. Be sure to keep a damp towel over the wrappers while you are working with them to keep them from drying out. I also placed a damp paper towel over the rolled lumpia. I ended up freezing about half of them to fry at a later time. My package of wrappers contained 25 wrappers. Using 1-1/2 times the recipe, I did have a little bit of filling left after making the 25 rolls. Will make these again! Thanks for the recipe!
Great recipe
No but next time, I will add raisins and green peas. I remember having them in the lumpia and it made it even more delicious.
Turns out perfect every time.
The best lupus EVER!!! easy fun but they won't last! My kids steal them. I made 150 of them put them in the freezer and slowly but surely they all vanished!!!

My husband and I made this together as part of date night! The lumpia was amazing and totally delicious - way better than a restaurant! Thank you so much for sharing this recipe, we will definitely be making this again.

Made this last night, doubled the recipe, added shredded mushrooms as well, and kept the meat mixture raw. You can wrap them without cooking the meat mixture first. The oil always ends up cooking the meat to the prefect temp. Perfect for dipping in sweet chili sauce
Yes I would make it again, but with more garlic and soy sauce. No need to add garlic powder. Added turmeric.
Skipped the salt because there is enough natural and didn't miss it's. My frying times were double but not a problem because it is based upon color.Will make it again
I made this without pork and it was very good I would assume it would be delish with pork too!

Perfect, but don't use cilantro. There aren't any Filipino dishes that use cilantro, and it changes the flavor profile significantly. Instead of cilantro, use grated or minced ginger. I omitted the green cabbage, and used bok choy instead because that's what I had on hand.

For authentic dipping sauce, use finely diced garlic and white vinegar (Datu Puti brand has cane sugar) in 1:1 ratio. Ang sarap!
Came out really delicious. Will be making again.

A little light on spice but very good! I grew up eating lumpia that had French style green beans so I added them to my lumpia. I doubled the garlic and soy sauce to our taste. Also added water chestnuts because it's the only way I can get my oldest dauggter to eat them. They turned out so good! I'll definitely be making these again!
Outstanding!
Better than what you get at any filipino restaurants. Such a huge hit everytime I make it! Thank you for sharing!!

Excellent Recipe. My mom used to make them with beef and pork (seasoned), and would cook shredded carrots and potatoes with the meat. She would let it sit in the fridge overnight to let the juices go to the bottom, and allow the seasoning to marinate into the mixture.
I doubled the recipe for more rolls based on previous reviews. I prefer more cabbage so I plan on using more my next go around. My daughter and her friends loved the recipe!!

I jumped at this recipe as it immediately reminded me of the huge Lumpia wrapped in a lettuce leaf I used to get from Lien's restaurant in Guam as a young Lieutenant. On the eating side, this recipe has great flavor...the whole family liked them. Only down side was in production. I gained a new appreciate for the folks who wrap these things for a living. I was only able to find "Spring Roll" paper...so perhaps that was part of the problem??? But I really struggled with getting them wrapped well, so they wouldn't fall apart in the oil and stick to everything. It got better towards the end of the batch, so recommend you try a batch to experiment with before you try to impress anyone with a meal. Soaking the wrappers for a shorter period and turning up the oil heat to medium high seamed to help. The final product still ended up much greasier than I expected or would have liked. I'm not going to give up on this one. Suggestions?

Delicious recipe! I used more filling in each wrapper than is traditional, so next time I'll make more filling. I used about 12 wrappers for the amount of filling I had. We left out the cabbage since we're not big on cabbage and would've wasted the rest of a head of cabbage.
I’ve made this several times and it is a favorite!! I add more vegi’s but it is perfect the way it is!
I’ve made this several times and it is a favorite!! I add more vegi’s but it is perfect the way it is!
This has waaaaay too much salt!!! Great ingredients, don’t add that much salt. Always taste your lumpia filling before rolling them up!

My first time ever making Lumpia, and boy this recipe did not disappoint. The filling is absolutely seasoned just right and easily modified if you'd like more cilantro, carrot, or something else. Rolling these little suckers did test my patience, but once I got the hang of the process it was smooth sailing. Thanks for a great recipe that I'll be making again.

This is absolutely authentic! Making the pork mixture was the easiest part for me. From start to finish it took me longer than what the recipe states. I bought frozen lumpia sheets and I had to wait until they thawed and pulling them apart was quite difficult. I looked online and found keeping a damp napkin on the lumpia sheets as you rolled kept the sheets from drying/hardening on the edges through out.
No changes very tasty will make again
It was a 10 to my son in law, I thought they were good as well as my family...would make them again for sure. Was easy to make n prep was simple too.??

Made mine with 50/50 turkey meat and 90% lean ground meat. Turned out ok except the fact they have to cook low and slow if u mix and stuff all ingredients RAW as suggested per other reviews rendering them “greasy”. Will try to cook it again using “pre cooked meat” and “pre sautéed” veggies as recipe originally called for to see if that makes a difference. Other than that, great flavors!!!
Yummy. good flavor. the hardest part was wrapping the filling. It looks a lot easier than it is. But once I got the hang of it, it got a lot easier to roll.
These were SO good. We forgot to take a picture before everyone tore into them. So, we got a picture of these 3; but, there were no leftovers. Very quick, easy & delicious.
This tastes so good! It was my first time making lumpia and they came out sooo good! My boyfriend has been begging me to make them again!
loved this! used a sweet Thai chili sauce for dipping
1st time I made as is and I'd give it 4 stars. 2nd time I added sesame oil, Korean beef powdered soup base, and a little sugar to even it out. Now it's 5 stars.
i didnt change a thing in this recipe.. i love it. will make it again,thanks alot
I added a small bit of grated ginger and about 2T cilantro. They remind me of what I cooked in HI.

I just came back from the philippines where I ate these alot. Good recipe, substituted egg roll wrappers due to availability. People talking about salty have to realize Filipino soy sauce has very minimal amount of salt so if you use salt in this recipe you need to have a very low salt soy sauce.

My fiance is filipino and I am trying to explore more of his food culture and make more of the foods he likes. I chose this as my first recipe and it was a hit! All enjoyed it very much, thanks for the recipe!

I don't think I've ever had them before, let alone make them. We're pretty rural here on the Central California coast, but I managed to find a Asian market for Lumpia wrappers. The rest was easy and frying no time at all. Delicious.
made this with the pancit recipe i found here as well...what a delicious and easy recipe for anyone that has never made lumpia before.

I quadrupled the recipe to make it for an event and it turned out fantastic! My grandmother was in the Philippines so I couldn’t bother her for her recipe, but this came out extremely close. Nothing but raves on this recipe.
Excellent! I did not make any alterations to the recipe and they tasted great! My husband is a very picky eater but he loved these.

Very similar to how my Lola made lumpia while growing up in Cali. You can try different variations for the filling. One of my fave is ground beef with a cup of very small diced potatoes, in addition to the cabbage, carrots, etc. Serve w/white rice and store bought sweet & sour chili sauce..or, homemade vinegar sauce w garlic. Yum

this was pretty much spot on as far as flavor goes. I grew up eating this, and this was the taste I remeber. The only thing I altered was the meat. I had a section of pork rump roast, so I cooked it in the slow cooker with all the seasonings; it was super tender and flavorful. Then I added the cabbage and carrots to the meat in a pan to cook them up together. The flavor was spot on.
Very good. Loved them!
We all liked these A LOT. I wasn't sure if I would like the pork, but I did. Great flavor. We will make these again.

If you are a novice to this type of cooking, I suggest you take a class. I believe when recipe says to put three heaping tablespoons of the mixture They really mean three heaping TEASPOONS.. I did not have lumpia wrappers, and elsewhere on the Internet I was shown that Spring roll wrappers would work. However, the spring roll wrappers i used did not do very well. I should've known after rolling and being out of mixture at a count of 13 that I had put too much in these. They exploded in the grease and made a horrible mess. I'll try again another time, after my wounds have been licked, and make sure I have authentic lumpier wrappers. I will definitely only put a generous tablespoon next time and use common sense. The filling was tasty, though. Good luck to you!
I had a hard time telling if the meat inside was cooked all the way. And I think I need to add more seasoning.

Have always loved lumpia but when the Asian supermarket I used to buy them from closed I figured I'd take a try at making them myself. Ran across this recipe and I'm so glad I did. Simple easy ingredients. Trying to roll them was tricky for me at first but once I got the hang of it, no problem. Followed as written. Keeper!

I had found a couple of recipes for lumpia here and saved them to my favorites. I made the other one a couple of times since it was pork and shrimp, and today I accidentally grabbed this one before realizing it didn't have shrimp. Decided to add shrimp to it anyway, and these were fantastic! Even my super picky son ate 2 or 3. They were much more flavorful than the other recipe I had saved. Thanks so much for sharing.
Added peas and red bell pepper. It was decided that it would be good to stuff mini peppers with it. That turned out very nice!

I found a recipe on another site to bake at 400*F for 15 minutes. I brushed sesame oil on the Lumpia before baking. I baked instead of fried so my husband can take to work. Fried doesn't taste very good cold. (I baked for 19 minutes - oven issues) I also had prepackaged coleslaw. Saves time.
Delicious! I will definitely make it again!

this was delish. it took some getting used to when it came to wrapping. I'm used to egg rolls so my lumpia were a little thick in the beginning. but, the taste was there. I spoke to several who made these and was told if using ground pork NOT to fry it first so I didnt. it cooked great during the frying. easy enough to make and tasted great with my pancit!
I omit the additional salt and cabbage. I also mix all the ingredients raw and fill the lumpia. This is the way I was taught by my daughters Filipino BFFs Mom.
These were a HUGE hit at my last party.

No changes and yes I would make it again. I would possibly add a bit more spice. ** Let's put it this way...I'm up at 1:30am working on the computer and I'm fighting the urge to go downstairs and have a cold one from the fridge. (I recommend making a sweet sauce and a Hot Mustard sauce for heat) Delicious!

I grew up making lumpia with family friends every year for thanks giving and Christmas. We'd make a couple hundred at a time This recipe is very close to theirs except they did not cook the meat first. the mix was made and put into the wrap raw, rolled up and then cooked by my friend's mom.
I made it but also added carrots, 1/2 tsp of Cummin, 2 Tbl of fish sauce, 2 Tbl of hoisin sauce.
i used beef -but this was just a guide for me -i am a lucky lady-my sister is filipino- so i have the inside scoop--YUMMY !!!

Delicious and just as I remembered from my childhood. I used my food processor to shred the cabbage and carrots to get the pieces nice and small. I used the slicer for the cabbage and the grader for the carrots. Make sure your oil is hot enough so they are crisp and not soggy. Will make again!

Hubby made these, the hardest part was finding the Lumpia dough to make it with. On the advice of the clerk at the Asian Marketplace. We used the Spring Rolls dough. Turned out pretty good. We'll use sweet onion next time as we thought the green onions dominated the taste. Made the homemade sweet n sour sauce which was a nice compliment to the rolls.
Very tasty! My boyfriend who eats virtually nothing actually enjoyed this!
A word of advice...Use spring rolls! I found out the hard way that egg roll is not the same as spring roll!! Cooking the meat first, for me, made it harder to roll.

The only changes I made, were to add some diced celery and added a table spoon of sesame oil while stir frying the veggies. It was awesome. I made 60 total for Football Sunday...however with my family...they didn't make it past Saturday night.
1Tbs per wrapper makes 30 eggrolls. 3Tbs per wrapper makes only 10 eggrolls
They turned out awesome just use the recipe!
